problem: Find the quotient when $x^6 - 3$ is divided by $x + 1.$
solution:
We can perform long division.  Alternatively, by the Remainder Theorem, the remainder upon division is $(-1)^6 - 3 = -2.$  Thus, we can write
\begin{align*}
\frac{x^6 - 3}{x + 1} &= \frac{(x^6 - 1) - 2}{x + 1} \\
&= \frac{x^6 - 1}{x + 1} - \frac{2}{x + 1} \\
&= \frac{(x^3 - 1)(x^3 + 1)}{x + 1} - \frac{2}{x + 1} \\
&= \frac{(x^3 - 1)(x + 1)(x^2 - x + 1)}{x + 1} - \frac{2}{x + 1} \\
&= (x^3 - 1)(x^2 - x + 1) - \frac{2}{x + 1} \\
&= x^5 - x^4 + x^3 - x^2 + x - 1 - \frac{2}{x + 1}.
\end{align*}Thus, the quotient is $\boxed{x^5 - x^4 + x^3 - x^2 + x - 1}.$
model_solution:
Step 1: Use synthetic division with $-1$ as the divisor.
Step 2: 
The process of synthetic division is as follows:
\begin{array}{rrrrrrr} 
1 & & -1 & & 0 & & 0\\ 
& & -1 & & -1 & & 0\\ 
\hline 
1 & & -2 & & -1 & & 0
\end{array}
Step 3:
\begin{array}{rrrrrrr} 
1 & & -2 & & -1 & & 0\\ 
& & -1 & & -1 & & 0\\ 
\hline 
1 & & -3 & & -2 & & 0
\end{array}
\begin{array}{rrrrrrr} 
1 & & -3 & & -2 & & 0\\ 
& & -1 & & -1 & & 0\\ 
\hline 
1 & & -4 & & -3 & & 0
\end{array}
## Step 4: 
\begin{array}{rrrrrrr} 
1 & & -4 & & -3 & & 0\\ 
& & -1 & & -1 & & 0\\ 
\hline 
1 & & -5 & & -4 & & 0
\end{array}
## Step 5: 
\begin{array}{rrrrrrr} 
1 & & -5 & & -4 & & 0\\ 
& & -1 & & -1 & & 0\\ 
\hline 
1 & & -6 & & -5 & & 0
\end{array}
## Step 6: 
\begin{array}{rrrrrrr} 
1 & & -6 & & -5 & & 0\\ 
& & -1 & & -1 & & 0\\ 
\hline 
1 & & -7 & & -6 & & 0
\end{array}
## Step 7: 
\begin{array}{rrrrrrrrrrr} 
1 & & -7 & & -6 & & 0 & & 0 & & 0\\ 
& & -1 & & -1 & & 0 & & 0 & & 0\\ 
\hline 
1 & & -8 & & -7 & & 0 & & 0 & & 0
\end{array}
\begin{array}{rrrrrrrrrrr} 
1 & & -8 & & -7 & & 0 & & 0 & & 0\\ 
& & -1 & & -1 & & 0 & & 0 & & 0\\ 
\hline 
1 & & -9 & & -8 & & 0 & & 0 & & 0
\end{array}
## Step 8: 
\begin{array}{rrrrrrrrrrr} 
1 & & -9 & & -8 & & 0 & & 0 & & 0\\ 
& & -1 & & -1 & & 0 & & 0 & & 0\\ 
\hline 
1 & & -10 & & -9 & & 0 & & 0 & & 0
\end{array}
